issues.title: SHOULD is insufficiently described
issues.author: chris-box
issues.body:
During shepherd review, I've identified that the current text deviates from the content guidelines, which may make it difficult to pass Last Call and IESG review. 

This github issue is about one of those.

Nearly all the uses of SHOULD in the document fail to state:
- valid reasons for varying from the recommendation, and
- the implications of doing so.

To resolve this, the above could be added, or alternatively we could downgrade to the non-normative should.

issues.title: Security Considerations too short
issues.author: chris-box
issues.body:
The content guidelines say

> The text of [the Security Considerations] section must have a meaningful exploration of security issues raised by the proposal, which should include both risks and a description of solutions or workarounds. It is rare that technical work can legitimately make a claim like "This protocol introduces no security considerations," so it needs to be fairly obvious for that to be believable, or the document will be returned for further development. Procedural documents, however, more commonly can claim no added security risk.

I think the sentence:

> The addition of a record lifetime to facilitate automated garbage collection does not itself add any significant new security concerns.

struggles to meet the threshold of "meaningful". Can we articulate the types of attacks we have thought about (e.g. extremely short lifetimes), and our conclusion that they are not a problem?

issues.title: Timers
issues.author: chris-box
issues.body:
The "common issues" for TSV area include this one:

> If a protocol contains timers, the reviewer should consider whether there is a default value given, or a formula/algorithm for managing the timer. Is there potential for multiple nodes, connections, or other protocol instances have their timers synchronize and cause undesirable effects? E.g. should the timer be randomly dithered.

We have these timers:
LEASE (requestor SHOULD be >=1800, server can do what they like)
KEY-LEASE (ditto)
UDP initial retry (SHOULD be 2s)
UDP retry backoff algorithm (SHOULD be doubling)

To meet the criteria we'll need to add default values or say something else about it. And we'll need to consider undesirable effects. Links to issue #10.

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body:
The current requirements for the timers are rather deterministic; so a possible scenario where synchronization occurs is e.g. an entire floor/wing of lighting IoT devices where power is switched off and switched on again. These IoT lights would then all try to register via SRP, with update-lease option, at about the same time. And also reregister at 75% of lease time all around the same time.

* In lighting systems, it's quite common to have 100s/1000s of identical (networked) devices. So these would all register an identical service with identical lease time, if they would use DNS-SD / SRP. (Use of SRP for such systems is uncommon today but may be used in the future.)

Probably the term 'SHOULD' was used for these timers to allow some local variation. But it may be better to make that explicit. E.g. "re-register after 70-90% of lease time expired at a random time" or so.

comments.author: chris-box
comments.body: I tend to agree that explicit wording on variation would be better.

issues.title: Editorial
issues.author: chris-box
issues.body:
A few minor improvements can be made.

The first was identified by Tony Zhou in WGLC review: Section 4.1 "continue sending refresh messages (see below) as if the server", here "refresh" may be capitalized since other appearances of "Refresh message" in the article are capitalized.

At the top of section 5, it should probably read "in order to prevent the update's records from being garbage collected."

In 5.1, the paragraph starting "The Refresh message SHOULD NOT" could be made easier to parse. Essentially they are saying don't add prerequisites that would cause the update to fail under either possible server state.

The following abbreviations lack expansions on first use, which is required by the content guidelines. These ones are not considered well-known in the RFC Editor's abbreviations list:
	EDNS(0) 	Extension Mechanisms for DNS (EDNS(0))
	DNS-SD   DNS-based Service Discovery (DNS-SD)

issues.title: 10ms accuracy? is that too fine?
issues.author: Abhayakara
issues.body:
Chris Box has raised the issue that a granularity of 10ms might be hard for some low-power devices, hence we shouldn't use a MUST.

My proposed fix for this is to say "this restriction applies to the scheduling of the response. The network physical layer or link layer protocol may constrain the time at which the packet is actually sent."

comments.author: Abhayakara
comments.body: Updated in previous commit. Clarification is that 10ms is the schedule, but we can't control when the packet is actually transmitted.

issues.title: Lease time variance is unclear
issues.author: Abhayakara
issues.body: We currently say 75% +/- 10%. This is unclear. It's also arguably too broad a range—maybe we should do 80-85%?

comments.author: Abhayakara
comments.body:
<t>In order to prevent records expiring, requestors MUST refresh resource records before they
	expire. At the time of registration, the client computes an interval that is 80% of the lease
	time plus a random offset between 0 and 5% of the lease time. The random offset is to prevent
	refreshes from being synchronized. When this interval has expired, the client MUST refresh the
	message if the data in the initial Registration should continue to be advertised.</t>

issues.title: Minimum (non-retransmission) update interval
issues.author: Abhayakara
issues.body: Personal thought: "Servers MUST have a minimum interval before which they will not accept" could be made a bit easier to parse, e.g. "Servers MUST have a minimum interval for accepting Refreshes. Such messages that arrive before that time MUST be silently ignored."

comments.author: Abhayakara
comments.body:
<t>There may be some cost associated with renewing leases. A malicious (or buggy) client
      could renew at a high rate in order to overload the server more than it would be
      overloaded by query traffic. This risk is present for regular DNS update as well. The
      server MUST enforce a minimum interval between updates. After a Refresh or Registration
      has been successfully processed and acknowledged, another Update of either type from the
      client during that interval MUST be silently ignored by the server.</t>

issues.title: From Esko Dijk: 4-byte versus 8-byte unclarity
issues.author: Abhayakara
issues.body:
There was one possible unclarity, raised by the recent discussion on “SRP use of Update Lease option variants”:
Text states:
 
                Note that both the 4-byte and 8-byte variant are valid on both clients and servers. If a server receives a 4-byte variant, it MUST respond with a 4-byte variant.
 
Does this sentence combo mean:
Server MUST support 4-byte and 8-byte variant; and
Client MUST support 4-byte and 8-byte variant.
 
Or rather does it mean:
Server MUST support 4-byte and 8-byte variant; and
Client MUST support 4-byte variant and MAY support 8-byte variant.   (Since a 4-byte-only client would never receive an 8-byte variant!)
 
Did we intend to say the former, or the latter, or leave it in the middle? In practice a client can be implemented fully without support for the 8-byte variant regardless of our intentions here.
So not even sure we need to do anything here, but wanted to highlight the potential unclarity.

comments.author: Abhayakara
comments.body: This was addressed in the post-wglc update.

comments.author: Abhayakara
comments.body:
These changes are actually inconsistent. We say "the latest update or refresh", which used to not be capitalized, and this means the latest action that was taken on the database, not the message that triggered that action. So either it should be "update message or refresh message" or it should be "update or refresh," not "update or refresh message."

I think the idea of capitalizing "Refresh" was to distinguish between the message and the transaction, but maybe I'm misremembering. Anyway, can you give this a think and see what occurs to you? I don't want to just ignore this pull request, but I don't think it's ready yet. :]

I was concerned I had gotten inconsistent, and you are correct.  

Initially I was making sure the document said "refresh message" when it was referring to one. 

I do like your idea of using "Refresh" for the message, but I would suggest writing "Refresh message" (or "refresh message" i'm open)  when it is the message.  Maybe that is overly obvious but it wasn't always to me. 

Can you look at this update?

The text feels like it's tugging us in the direction that Refresh messages are a distinct message type, but they're not. So I think this PR makes things worse, not better.
